revision.text:
{{advert|date=November 2018}} {{distinguish|Johnson & Johnson}} {{refimprove|date=September 2015}} {{Infobox company | name = S. C. Johnson & Son, Inc. | logo = SC Johnson 2018.svg | logo_caption = Current S. C. Johnson logo | image = Johnsonwax01.jpg | image_caption = [[Johnson Wax Headquarters]] | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | industry = [[Fast-moving consumer goods|Consumer goods]] | founded = {{Start date and age|1886}}
[[Racine, Wisconsin]], U.S. | founder = [[Samuel Curtis Johnson Sr.]] | hq_location = 1525 Howe Street | hq_location_city = [[Racine, Wisconsin]] | hq_location_country = United States | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = [[Herbert Fisk Johnson III]] ([[Chairman]] & [[Chief executive officer|CEO]]) | brands = {{Unbulleted list|Shout|Babyganics|Windex|Mr. Muscle|[[Kit (brand)|Kit]]|[[Baygon]]|[[Sodium hypochlorite|Bayclin]]|Ziploc|Glade|Brise|Kiwi|Raid|OFF!|Kabikiller|Pledge|Scrubbing Bubbles|Caldrea|Mrs. Meyer's Clean Day|Drano|Toilet Duck|Fantastik|Autan|Saran}} | revenue = {{nowrap|[[United States dollar|US$]] 11.75 billion}} | revenue_year = 2013 | owner = Johnson Family | num_employees = 13,000{{cite web|title=SC Johnson What We Do|url=http://www.scjohnson.com/en/company/what-we-do.aspx|website=www.scjohnson.com}} | website = {{URL|scjohnson.com}} }} [[File:SC Johnson Logo.svg|thumb|Previous SC Johnson logo|right|120px]] '''S. C. Johnson & Son, Inc.''' (commonly referred to as '''S. C. Johnson''', previously '''S. C. Johnson Wax''' and '''Johnson Wax''') is an American [[multinational corporation|multinational]] privately held manufacturer of household cleaning supplies and other consumer chemicals based in [[Racine, Wisconsin]].{{Cite web | title = What We Do | url = http://www.scjohnson.com/en/company/what-we-do.aspx | publisher = S. C. Johnson & Son | access-date = March 29, 2018}} In 2017, S. C. Johnson employed approximately 13,000 and had estimated sales of $10 billion.{{Citation | last = Byron | first = Ellen | title = How Fisk Johnson Works to Keep the Shine on Family Business | newspaper = The Wall Street Journal | date = March 9, 2016 | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/how-fisk-johnson-works-to-keep-the-shine-on-family-business-1457605802 | access-date = March 29, 2018}} The company is owned by the Johnson family. [[Herbert Fisk Johnson III | H. Fisk Johnson]], Chairman and CEO since 2004, is the fifth generation of the Johnson family to lead the company.{{Citation | last = Delwiche | first=Anna | title = Continuing the Family Legacy: Fisk Johnson’s Donation and His Family’s Commitment to Cornell | newspaper = The Cornell Daily Sun | date = January 29, 2017 | url = http://cornellsun.com/2017/01/29/continuing-the-family-legacy-fisk-johnsons-donation-and-his-familys-commitment-to-cornell/ | access-date = March 29, 2018}} == History == The company is one of the oldest family-owned businesses in the U.S,{{Citation | last = Cowen | first = Lee | title = In Good Company: A Family History at SC Johnson | newspaper = CBS Sunday Morning | date = October 16, 2016 | url = https://www.cbsnews.com/news/a-family-history-at-sc-johnson/ | access-date = April 3, 2018}} beginning in 1886 when [[Samuel Curtis Johnson, Sr. | Samuel Curtis Johnson]] purchased the parquet flooring division from the Racine Hardware Manufacturing Company and named the new business S. C. Johnson. The company’s principal product at that time was parquet flooring, later adding other floor care products like Johnson’s Prepared Wax, Johnson’s Dance Wax and Johnson’s Wood Dye.{{Citation | last = Pfankuchen | first = David | title = Parquet Floors Launched Firm | newspaper = The Journal Times | date = September 21, 1986 | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/342875541/ | access-date = April 3, 2018}} Under [[Herbert Fisk Johnson Sr.]], the company expanded worldwide, establishing its first subsidiary in England in 1914.{{Citation | last = Pfankuchen | first = David | title = Parquet Floors Launched Firm | newspaper = The Journal Times | date = September 21, 1986 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/342875541/ | access-date = April 23, 2018}} Giving his employees credit for a successful year, Herbert gave them $35,000 in 1917.{{Citation | author = Staff Writer | title = Johnson Gives His Employes [sic] Credit for Successful Year | newspaper = The Racine Journal-News | date = December 22, 1917 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/333942445/ | access-date = March 29, 2018}}{{Citation | author = Staff Writer | title = Herbert F. Johnson Dies, Victim of Heart Disease | newspaper = The Racine Times-Call | date = February 16, 1928 | access-date = March 29, 2018}} In 1932, SC Johnson introduced Johnson’s Glo-Coat.{{Citation | author = Staff Writer | title = New Product is Now on the Market | newspaper = The Racine Journal-News | date = April 29, 1932 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/334283361/ | access-date = March 29, 2018}} The success of Glo-Coat bolstered the company during the Great Depression.{{Citation | last = Burke | first = Michael | title = The Flight That Changed a Company | newspaper = The Journal Times | date = October 22, 2001 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/343337216/ | access-date = April 3, 2018}} S. C. Johnson’s line of wax-reliant products necessitated [[Herbert Fisk Johnson Jr.]]’s 1935 expedition to Fortaleza, Brazil to find a direct sustainable source of wax.{{Citation | author = Staff Writer | title = Wax Hunt | newspaper = Time | date = October 14, 1935 | access-date = April 3, 2018}} From April 1935 until May 1950, the company was the sponsor for the [[Fibber McGee and Molly]] [[Golden Age of Radio|radio show]], officially known as ''The Johnson Wax Program''.{{Citation | last1 = Stumpf | first1 = Charles | last2 = Price | first2 = Tom | title = Heavenly Days! The Story of Fibber McGee and Molly | place = Waynesville, NC | publisher = The World of Yesterday | pages = 41-202 | date = 1987 | isbn =0-936505-05-2}} During the 1950s, the company served as sponsor of the game show, ''[[The Name's the Same]]''.{{Citation | author = Staff Writer | title = Rival TV Networks Share The Honors: NBC and ABC both take lively part in one of TV’s biggest success stories | newspaper = LIFE | date = April 13, 1953 | url = https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=4kgEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA169&lpg=PA169&dq=%22the+name's+the+same%22+%22sc+johnson%22&source=bl&ots=vfHBOjOOEx&sig=Dl06LdpcVspapgvTrET2NH0Thrg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiZ_K3Nh8faAhVoUN8KHckBA5UQ6AEIPzAE#v=onepage&q=%22the%20name's%20the%20same%22%20%22sc%20johnson%22&f=false | access-date = April 19, 2018}} The company went on to co-sponsor ''[[Robert Montgomery Presents]]'' on [[NBC]], and ''[[The Red Skelton Show]]'' on [[CBS]].{{Citation | author = Staff Writer | title = S. C. Johnson & Son | website = AdAge.com | publisher = Crane Communications | date = September 15, 2003 | url = http://adage.com/article/adage-encyclopedia/s-c-johnson-son/98732/| access-date = April 19, 2018}} In April of 1939, the [[Frank Lloyd Wright]]-designed SC Johnson Administration Building opened.{{Citation | author = Staff Writer | title = New Frank Lloyd Wright Office Building Shows Shape of Things to Come | newspaper = LIFE | date = May 8, 1939 | url = https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=rEkEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA15&dq=%22New+Frank+Lloyd+Wright+Office+Building+Shows+Shape+of+Things+to+Come%22+%22sc+johnson%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjotf-Vk8faAhXmdN8KHWtjDKYQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=%22New%20Frank%20Lloyd%20Wright%20Office%20Building%20Shows%20Shape%20of%20Things%20to%20Come%22%20%22sc%20johnson%22&f=false | access-date = April 19, 2018}} Its addition, the Research Tower, opened in 1950.{{Citation | author = Staff Writer | title = Speaking of Pictures: Johnson’s new “Heliolab” makes strange patterns both by night and by day | newspaper = LIFE | date = December 11, 1950 | url = https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=yEsEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA31&dq=%22LIFE%22+December+11,+1950+%22rex+harrison%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwinuJG5lcfaAhVSh-AKHdtyBgsQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=Johnson&f=false | access-date = April 19, 2018}} The [[Johnson Wax Headquarters | SC Johnson Headquarters]] was designated a [[National Historic Landmark]] in 1974.{{Citation | title = National Register of Historic Places Inventory – Nomination Form - S. C. Johnson and Son, Inc. | website = nps.gov | publisher = National Parks Service | date = December 27, 1974 | url = https://npgallery.nps.gov/AssetDetail/NRIS/74002275 | access-date = April 19, 2018}} The launch of Raid House & Garden Bug Killer in 1955 marked the company’s first major departure away from wax-based products.{{Citation | last = Cowen | first = Lee | title = In Good Company: A Family History at SC Johnson | newspaper = CBS Sunday Morning | date = October 16, 2016 | url = https://www.cbsnews.com/news/a-family-history-at-sc-johnson/ | access-date = April 19, 2018}} Within the next few years, [[Samuel Curtis Johnson, Jr. | Sam Johnson]], fourth generation leader, introduced some of the company’s best known: [[Glade (brand) |Glade]], [[Off! (brand) |OFF!]] and [[Pledge (brand) | Pledge]].{{Citation | last = Johnson | first = Samuel C. | title = The Essence Of A Family Enterprise | place = Indianapolis, Indiana | publisher = The Curtis Publishing Company | pages = 49-50, 63, 65, 70-72 | date = 1988 | isbn =0-89387-086-2}} In April 2018, the company updated their [[tagline]] from “A Family Company,” which began in 1998, to “A Family Company at Work for a Better World.” According to the company, the updated tagline is “A reminder that SC Johnson holds itself to a higher standard.”{{Cite news|url=http://journaltimes.com/business/local/sc-johnson-updates-its-slogan-a-family-company-at-work/article_3d3df663-2caf-5458-8283-824d036ec3d1.html|title=SC Johnson updates its slogan: 'A Family Company at Work for a Better World'|last=Times|first=For The Journal|work=Journal Times|access-date=2018-04-24|language=en}} ===Acquisition milestones=== * In 1992, the company bought [[Drackett]], manufacturer of [[Windex]], [[Drano|Drāno]] and other specialty cleaning products.{{Citation | author = The Associated Press | title = Company News; S.C. Johnson to Buy Drackett from Bristol-Myers | newspaper = The New York Times | date = October 28, 1992 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1992/10/28/business/company-news-sc-johnson-to-buy-drackett-from-bristol-myers.html | access-date = April 20, 2018}} * In 1998, S. C. Johnson expanded its roster of consumer brands when it purchased [[Dow Chemical]]'s DowBrands division, which included [[Ziploc]], [[Saran (plastic)|Saran]], [[Fantastik]], and [[Scrubbing Bubbles]].{{Citation | title = S.C. Johnson completes Dow acquisition | newspaper = Milwaukee Business Journal | date = January 23, 1998 | url = https://www.bizjournals.com/milwaukee/stories/1998/01/19/daily15.html | access-date = April 20, 2018}} * In 1999, the commercial cleaning products and systems division separated from Johnson Wax and became a stand-alone company called Johnson Wax Professional, later known as [[Diversey, Inc.]]{{Citation | last1 = Callahan | first1 = Patricia | last2 = Ellison | first2 = Sarah | title = Johnson Wax to Buy DiverseyLever From Unilever for About $1.6 Billion | newspaper = The Wall Street Journal | date = November 21, 2001 | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB1006273941922577320| access-date = April 20, 2018}} * In 2008 the company acquired Caldrea, Co, maker of household cleaning products including the ''Caldrea'' and ''Mrs. Meyers Clean Day'' brands.{{Citation | last = Hamlin | first = Doug | title = S.C. Johnson buys Caldrea | newspaper = Minneapolis/St. Paul Business Journal | date = April 28, 2008 | url = https://www.bizjournals.com/twincities/stories/2008/04/28/daily12.html | access-date = April 20, 2018}} * S. C. Johnson acquired Deb Group in 2015. A year later the company announced a new line of SC Johnson Professional products at the ISSA/INTERCLEAN conference in Chicago.{{Citation | last = Schuyler | first = David | title = S.C. Johnson announces return to industrial and institutional market | newspaper = Milwaukee Business Journal | date = October 26, 2016 | url = https://www.bizjournals.com/milwaukee/news/2016/10/26/s-c-johnson-announces-return-to-industrial-and.html | access-date = April 20, 2018}} * In July 2016 the company signed an agreement to acquire Babyganics, a baby products company with skin care, oral care, sun care, insect repellent, diapers and wipe products.{{Citation | last = Barrow | first = Olivia | title = S.C. Johnson acquires fast-growing baby products company | newspaper = Milwaukee Business Journal | date = July 1, 2016 | url = https://www.bizjournals.com/milwaukee/news/2016/07/01/sc-johnson-acquires-fast-growing-baby-products.html| access-date = April 20, 2018}} * In 2017 the company signed an agreement to acquire cleaning brands Method and Ecover.{{Citation | last = Marotti | first = Ally | title = S.C. Johnson plans to acquire Method, which has a Pullman soap factory | newspaper = Chicago Tribune | date = September 15, 2017 | url = http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/ct-sc-johnson-acquires-method-soap-0916-biz-20170915-story.html | access-date = April 20, 2018}} ===Ingredients=== The company launched a website listing ingredients for their products sold in North America in 2009.{{Citation | author = GreenBiz Editors | title = SC Johnson Starts Listing Products Ingredients Publicly | newspaper = GreenBiz | date = March 13, 2009 | url = https://www.greenbiz.com/news/2009/03/13/sc-johnson-starts-listing-product-ingredients-publicly | access-date = April 23, 2018}} Fragrance ingredients were added to the list in 2012.{{Citation | last = King | first = Bart | title = SC Johnson Completes Full Disclosure if Fragrance Ingredients | newspaper = Chicago Tribune | date = September 15, 2017 | url = http://www.sustainablebrands.com/news_and_views/articles/sc-johnson-completes-full-disclosure-fragrance-ingredients | access-date = April 23, 2018}} The company added the ingredients of its European products to the list in May 2016.{{Citation | title = SC Johnson expands ingredient disclosure to Europe| newspaper = Chemical Watch | date = May 27, 2016 | url = https://chemicalwatch.com/47699/sc-johnson-expands-ingredient-disclosure-to-europe | access-date = April 23, 2018}} In May 2017, SC Johnson disclosed a list of 368 potential skin allergens in its products.{{Citation | last = Joyce | first = Stephen | title = SC Johnson to Expand Skin Allergen Disclosures in Products | newspaper = Bloomberg BNA | date = May 26, 2017 | url = https://www.bna.com/sc-johnson-expand-n73014451584/ | access-date = April 23, 2018}} == Brand names == Among the brands owned by S. C. Johnson & Son are the following: === Car care === {{see|car care}} * Grand Prix * Tempo === Floor care === {{see|Floor cleaning}} * Glo-Coat * Johnsons Brite * [[Mr Muscle]] * Plexon === Household cleaning and scent products === {{see|cleaning product|fragrance}} * Bayfresh * Beanpod Soy Candles * [[Blem (brand)]] * Caldrea * [[Drano]] * [[Ecover]]{{cite news |url=https://www.ft.com/content/258928f1-cf88-348c-9cc3-cc90ca4aca09 |title=SC Johnson scoops up Method, Ecover cleaning-product brands |last=Dye |first=Jessica |newspaper=Financial Times |date=14 September 2017 |accessdate=19 April 2018}} * [[Fantastik]] * Favor * [[Glade (brand)|Glade]] * Grab-it * KabiKiller (Japan) * Method * [[Mr Muscle]] * Mrs. Meyer's Clean Day * Nature's Source * Kiwi Dranex * Oust * [[Pledge (brand)|Pledge]] * Pride, furniture polish{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,898201,00.html|title=Johnson Merchandising: Johnson's Wash-'n'-Wax|journal=TIME|date=June 26, 1964 }} * [[Scrubbing Bubbles]] (formerly known as [[Dow Chemical Company|Dow]] Bathroom Cleaner before the sale to S. C. Johnson & Son) * Shout * [[Toilet Duck]] * [[Windex]] * Kiwi Dranex Kleen === Household food storage === * [[Saran (plastic)|Saran Wrap]] * [[Ziploc]] === Household pest control === * ALL OUT * Autan * [[Baygon]] * Fuyí ([[Argentina]]) * [[Off! (brand)|OFF!]] * [[Raid (insecticide)|Raid]] * Ridsect ([[Malaysia]]) === Shoe care === * Bama * Class * Grison * [[Kiwi (shoe polish)|Kiwi]] * Meltonian * Salamander * Tana * Woly * Woly Sport == Environmental record == S. C. Johnson & Son's Greenlist process is a classification system that evaluates the effects of raw materials on human health and the environment. The Greenlist logo represents an internal ratings system to help customers identify which products are environmentally safe. The Greenlist label is present in many S. C. Johnson & Son products. The Greenlist process has resulted in the elimination of 1.8 million pounds of [[volatile organic compound]]s from [[Windex]], and four million pounds of [[polyvinylidene chloride]] from [[Saran (plastic)|Saran Wrap]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cnnmoney.com|title=CNNMoney – Business, financial and personal finance news|publisher=}} In 2011, S. C. Johnson & Son settled a lawsuit that alleged the company's Greenlist label misled consumers into believing the products were reviewed by a third party and given a seal of approval. The company agreed to an undisclosed sum and dropped the labeling of Greenlist on Windex.{{Cite web|url=http://www.scjohnson.com/en/press-room/press-releases/07-08-2011/SC-Johnson-Settles-Cases-Involving-Greenlist-Labeling.aspx|title=SC Johnson Settles Cases Involving Greenlist Labeling {{!}} Press Room|website=www.scjohnson.com|access-date=2016-06-24}} S. C. Johnson & Son is the main sponsor of the [[Serra das Almas Private Natural Heritage Reserve]] in the states of [[Ceará]] and [[Piauí]], Brazil. The reserve protects an area of the [[caatinga]] biome, including wild specimens of the carnauba palm tree ([[Copernicia prunifera]]), the source of [[carnauba wax]].{{citation|language=Portuguese|publisher=Associação Caatinga |author=Rodrigo Castro |title=Reserva Natural Serra das Almas / CE |url=http://www.rppnweb.com/site_rppn/index.php/proprietarios-de-rppn/229-rodrigo-de-castro-reserva-natural-serra-das-almas-ce|accessdate=2016-05-18}} On December 18, 2012, S. C. Johnson & Son began operation of two [[wind turbine]]s at their largest manufacturing facility in [[Mount Pleasant, Wisconsin]]. The turbines, in addition to the gas reclamation system in place at a nearby landfill, are estimated to produce enough electricity to completely power the facility.{{cite web|url=http://www.scjohnson.com/en/press-room/press-releases/12-18-2012/SC-Johnson-Powers-Up-Wind-Energy-at-Largest-Mfg-Facility.aspx|title=SC Johnson Powers Up Wind Energy at Largest Mfg Facility – Press Room|work=scjohnson.com}} In 2017 S. C. Johnson purchased the ecological product Ecover and Method brands on undisclosed terms.{{cite news |url=https://www.ft.com/content/258928f1-cf88-348c-9cc3-cc90ca4aca09 |title=SC Johnson scoops up Method, Ecover cleaning-product brands |last=Dye |first=Jessica |newspaper=Financial Times |date=14 September 2017 |accessdate=19 April 2018}} == Controversy == A [[Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act|RICO]] lawsuit by tax whistleblower Mike DeGuelle alleges that since 1997, S. C. Johnson & Son has taken advantage of audit errors and filed fraudulent tax returns, underpaying its taxes by millions of dollars.{{Cite web | url=http://www.tax.com/taxcom/taxblog.nsf/Permalink/UBEN-8BTJ35?OpenDocument | title=Can Loopholes Blow the Whistle on Whistleblowers? | work=Tax.com | accessdate=2010-12-06 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716194036/http://www.tax.com/taxcom/taxblog.nsf/Permalink/UBEN-8BTJ35?OpenDocument | archivedate=2011-07-16 | df= }} H. Fisk Johnson ordered an inquiry into the allegations, and told [[Tax Analysts]] that he learned "other details of the decisions they (the tax department) made that I didn't like. I didn't like what I heard." On December 15, 2011, the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit]], in Case No. 10-2172, ruled that DeGuelle had alleged a valid claim that the company's discharge of him was part of the tax fraud scheme.{{Cite web | url=http://www.whistleblowersblog.org/2011/12/articles/corporate-1/major-victory-for-whistleblowers-in-seventh-circuit-says-retaliation-is-a-rico-violation/ | title=Major Victory for Whistleblowers in Seventh Circuit Says Retaliation is a RICO Violation | work=Whistleblowers Protection Blog | accessdate=2011-12-20}} S. C. Johnson & Son was fined by [[Autorité de la concurrence]] in France in 2016 for price-fixing on personal hygiene products.{{cite web |url=http://www.connexionfrance.com/court-appeal-price-fixing-fine-upheld-consumer-companies-gillette-loreal-procter-gamble-sc-johnson-18567-view-article.html |title=Huge price-fixing fine is upheld |publisher=The Connexion |date=28 October 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170209165431/http://www.connexionfrance.com/court-appeal-price-fixing-fine-upheld-consumer-companies-gillette-loreal-procter-gamble-sc-johnson-18567-view-article.html |archivedate=9 February 2017 |df= }} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == {{Portal|Wisconsin|Companies}} * {{Official website|http://www.scjohnson.com/}} * [https://www.WhatsInsideSCJohnson.com Company provided list of ingredients for Europe and North America] {{S. C. Johnson & Son}} {{S. C. Johnson family}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Johnson, S. C., and Son}} [[Category:Chemical companies of the United States]] [[Category:Multinational companies]] [[Category:Privately held companies based in Wisconsin]] [[Category:Privately held companies of the United States]] [[Category:American companies established in 1886]] [[Category:Samuel Curtis Johnson family]] [[Category:S. C. Johnson & Son| ]] [[Category:Companies based in Racine, Wisconsin]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies based in Wisconsin]] [[Category:1886 establishments in Wisconsin]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies established in 1886]]

{{Use British English|date=March 2015}}
[[File:Escasez en Venezuela, Central Madeirense 8.JPG|250px|thumbnail|right|A 2014 image of product [[shortages in Venezuela]].]]
In [[economics]], a '''shortage''' or '''excess demand''' is a situation in which the [[demand]] for a [[product (business)|product]] or [[service (economics)|service]] exceeds its [[supply (economics)|supply]] in a [[market (economics)|market]]. It is the opposite of an [[excess supply]] ([[economic surplus|surplus]]).
== Definitions == In a [[perfect market]] (one that matches a simple [[microeconomic]] model), an excess of demand will prompt sellers to increase [[price]]s until demand at that price matches the available supply, establishing [[economic equilibrium|market equilibrium]]<ref>Tucker (2014) Economics Today</ref>{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}. In economic terminology, a shortage occurs when for some reason (such as government intervention, or decisions by sellers not to raise prices) the price does not rise to reach equilibrium. In this circumstance, buyers want to purchase more at the market price than the quantity of the good or service that is available, and some non-price mechanism (such as "first come, first served" or a lottery) determines which buyers are served. So in a perfect market the only thing that can cause a shortage is price.
In common use, the term "shortage" may refer to a situation where most people are unable to find a desired good at an affordable price, especially where supply problems have increased the price. "[[Market clearing]]" happens when all buyers and sellers willing to transact at the prevailing price are able to find partners. There are almost always willing buyers at a lower-than-market-clearing price; the narrower technical definition doesn't consider failure to serve this demand as a "shortage", even if it would be described that way in a social or political context (which the simple model of [[supply and demand]] does not attempt to encompass).
== Causes == Shortages (in the technical sense) may be caused by: * [[Price ceiling]]s, a type of [[price control]] which involves a government-imposed limit on the price of a product service. * Anti-[[price gouging]] laws. * Government [[ban (law)|ban]] on the sale of a product or service, such as [[prostitution]] or certain [[recreational drug use|recreational drugs]]. * Decisions by suppliers not to raise prices, for example to maintain friendly relationships with potential future customers during a supply disruption. * [[Artificial scarcity]]
== Effects == Decisions which result in a below-market-clearing price help some people and hurt others. In this case, shortages may be accepted because they theoretically enable a certain portion of the population to purchase a product that they couldn't afford at the market-clearing price. The cost is to those who are willing to pay for a product and either can't, or experience greater difficulty in doing so.
In the case of [[government intervention]] in the market, there is always a trade-off with positive and negative effects. For example, a price ceiling may cause a shortage, but it will also enable a certain percentage of the population to purchase a product that they couldn't afford at market costs. Economic shortages caused by higher [[transaction costs]] and [[opportunity costs]] (e.g., in the form of lost time) also mean that the distribution process is wasteful. Both of these factors contribute to a decrease in aggregate wealth.
Shortages may cause:
* [[Black market]]s, illegal markets in which products that are unavailable in conventional markets are sold, or in which products with excess demand are sold at higher prices than in the conventional market. * Artificial controls of demand, such as time (such as waiting in line) and [[rationing]]. * Non-monetary bargaining methods, such as time (for example [[Queue area|queuing]]), [[nepotism]], or even violence. * [[Price discrimination]]. * The inability to purchase a product, and subsequent [[forced saving]].
== Examples == [[File:Entre Libertador y Chacao los indigentes sobrevive con desechos.webm|250px|thumb|right|Citizens of [[Caracas, Venezuela]] searching for food in garbage in 2016]] * [[Rationing in the United Kingdom]] occurred mainly during and after the world wars * From 1920 to 1933 during [[prohibition in the United States]], the creation of a black market for [[liquor]] was created due to the low supply of [[alcoholic beverages]]. * During the [[1973 oil crisis]], during which long lines and rationing was used to control demand. * In the former [[Soviet Union]] during the 1980s, prices were artificially low by fiat (i.e., high prices were outlawed). Soviet citizens waited in line (or "queued") for various [[Price controls|price-controlled]] goods and services such as cars, apartments, or some types of clothing. From the point of view of those waiting in line, such goods were in perpetual "short supply"; some of them were willing and able to pay more than the official price ceiling, but were legally prohibited from doing so. This method for determining the allocation of goods in short supply is known as "[[rationing]]". * From the mid-2000s through the 2010s, [[shortages in Venezuela]] occurred, due to the Venezuelan government's economic policies;<ref>{{Cite news|title = Venezuela seizes warehouses packed with medical goods, food|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-economy-idUSKCN0ID00A20141024|newspaper = Reuters|date = 2014-10-24|access-date = 2015-12-07}}</ref> such as relying on foreign imports while creating strict [[foreign exchange controls]], put price controls in place and having [[expropriation]]s result with lower domestic production. As a result of such shortages, Venezuelans had to search for products, wait in lines for hours and rationing was initiated, with the government allowing the purchase of a certain amount of products through [[fingerprint recognition]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Why are Venezuelans posting pictures of empty shelves?|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-trending-30710014|accessdate=10 January 2015|agency=BBC|date=8 January 2015}}</ref><ref name=REUTjan2015>{{cite news|last1=Cawthorne|first1=Andrew|title=In shortages-hit Venezuela, lining up becomes a profession|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/21/us-venezuela-shortages-idUSKBN0KU1BX20150121|accessdate=17 June 2015|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=21 January 2015}}</ref><ref name=WSJoct2014>{{cite news|last1=Schaefer Muñoz|first1=Sara|title=Despite Riches, Venezuela Starts Food Rationing; Government Rolls Out Fingerprint Scanners to Limit Purchases of Basic Goods; 'How Is it Possible We've Gotten to This Extreme'|url=https://online.wsj.com/articles/despite-riches-venezuela-starts-food-rationing-1414025667|accessdate=11 November 2014|agency=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|publisher=Dow Jones & Company Inc|date=22 October 2014}}</ref>
Whether an economic shortage of a certain good or service is beneficial or detrimental to society often depends on one's [[ethics|ethical]] and [[politics|political]] views. For instance, consider the shortage of recreational drugs discussed above, and the controversies around the use of such drugs. Likewise, consider the economic shortage of cars in the Soviet Union during the 1980s: On the one hand, people had to wait in line to buy a new car; on the other hand, cars were more affordable than they would have been at market prices.
== Shortages and "longages" == [[Garrett Hardin]] emphasised that a shortage of supply can just as well be viewed as a "longage" of [[demand]]. For instance, a shortage of food can just as well be called a longage of people ([[Human overpopulation|overpopulation]]). By looking at it from this view, he felt the problem could be better dealt with.<ref>[http://www.garretthardinsociety.org/videos/video_803_segment5.html Video Interview with Garrett Hardin: Longages and Overpopulation Predictions] Educational Communications program 803, 1990</ref>
==Labour shortage== In its narrowest definition, a labour shortage is an [[economics|economic condition]] in which employers believe there are insufficient qualified candidates (employees) to fill the [[demand|marketplace demands]] for [[employment]] at a wage that is mostly employer-determined. Such a condition is sometimes referred to by [[economist]]s as "an insufficiency in the [[labour force]]." An [[Aging in the American workforce|ageing population and a contracting workforce]] and a [[birth dearth]] may curb U.S. economic expansion for several decades, for example.<ref>[http://washingtonexaminer.com/news/business/2011/08/shrinking-labor-force-may-curb-us-expansion-two-decades Shrinking labour force may curb U.S. expansion for two decades]</ref>
===Wage factors=== [[Wage|Wage levels]] have been suggested as one way to measure a labour shortage. However, that often does not match people's common perceptions. For example, if wages alone are the best measure of labour shortages, then that would imply that doctors, instead of farm workers, should be imported because doctors are far more expensive than farm workers. However, there are institutionally-imposed limits on the number of doctors that are allowed to be licensed.{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} If foreign migrant workers were not allowed into a nation, farm wages may go up but probably not enough to approach the wages of doctors.
The [[Atlantic slave trade]] (which originated in the early 17th century but ended by the early 19th century) was said to have originated from perceived shortages of agricultural labour in the [[Americas]] (particularly in the [[Southern United States]]). It was thought that bringing African labor was the only means of [[malaria]] resistance available at the time.<ref>[http://www.malaria.com/blog/american-plasmodium-vivax "As American as…Plasmodium vivax?"]</ref> Ironically, malaria seems to itself have been introduced to the "New World" via the slave trade.<ref>[http://sciencedude.blog.ocregister.com/2011/12/26/uci-new-world-malaria-linked-to-slave-trade/166005/ "UCI: New World malaria linked to slave trade."]</ref>

Essays in Honor of Janos Kornai'', Cambridge, Massachusetts: MIT Press, 2000 * {{Citation|last1=Myant|first1=Martin|last2=Drahokoupil|first2=Jan|title=Transition Economies: Political Economy in Russia, Eastern Europe, and Central Asia|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell|year=2010|isbn=978-0-470-59619-7}}

A Supply Chain Perspective by HK Systems] * [http://www.memp.pratt.duke.edu/downloads/americas_new_immigrant_entrepreneurs.pdf "America's New Immigrant Entrepreneurs" ] - A Duke University Study * [http://www.gonewiththeworld.com/blog.php?sublist=(53)(50)(46)(27)(56)(58)(0) Criticism of high-tech shortage claims ] * [http://heather.cs.ucdavis.edu/itaa.real.html Disputation of High-tech Labor Shortage by Dr. Matloff] * [http://www.thepublicinterest.com/archives/2003fall/article2.html RAND Study on Alleged Shortage of Scientists] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080406232529/http://www.internationalbusinessreport.com/Press-room/2008/Business-constraints.asp Shortage of skilled workers knocks red tape off top of business constraints league table - {{Infobox person | name = Simon Arias | image = | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name above --> | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | residence = | nationality = American | citizenship = United States | education = | alma_mater = [[Mercyhurst University]] | occupation = [[Entrepreneur]] | years_active = | era = | employer = | known_for = Being the President/State Director at American Income Life Arias Agencies
| website = {{URL|http://simonarias.net/}} }}
'''Simon Arias''' is the President/State Director at [[American Income Life Insurance Company]] Arias Agencies.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Wolf: Higher minimum wage good for business, economy | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''timesleader.com''| date =31 March 2016 | url =https://www.timesleader.com/news/527104/wolf-higher-minimum-wage-good-for-business-economy | accessdate =15 June 2018}}</ref> He is the State General Agent for [[Pennsylvania]], [[West Virginia]], [[Maryland]], [[Tennessee]] and [[Florida]].<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Pittsburgh Post Gazette: Simon Arias: Raise Pennsylvania’s minimum wage | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''businessforafairminimumwage.org''| date = | url =https://www.businessforafairminimumwage.org/news/00821/pittsburgh-post-gazette-simon-arias-raise-pennsylvania%E2%80%99s-minimum-wage | accessdate =15 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =Cyndy | first =Lane | title =Want to be a Better Entrepreneur? Learn From Simon Arias! | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''smudailycampus.com''| date =4 April 2018 | url =http://www.smudailycampus.com/sm-supporters/want-to-be-a-better-entrepreneur-learn-from-simon-arias | accessdate =15 June 2018}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Simon Arias was born to a 19-year-old single mother in [[Youngstown, Ohio]]. He grew up in a dangerous neighborhood and was in and out of juvenile detention as a young adult.<ref>{{cite news | last =Gene | first =Swank | title =Five Ways To Stay Motivated And Hit Your Business Goals | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''forbes.com''| date =4 December 2017 | url =https://www.forbes.com/sites/theyec/2017/12/04/five-ways-to-stay-motivated-and-hit-your-business-goals/#5590f6905877 | accessdate =15 June 2018}}</ref>
Arias was educated at [[Ursuline High School (Youngstown, Ohio)|Youngstown-Ursuline]] where he captained the football team in his senior year when they became state champions.<ref>{{cite news | last =Gene | first =Swank | title =The Inspiring Story of Simon Arias, Entrepreneur, Philanthropist | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''medium.com''| date =14 September 2017 | url =https://medium.com/thrive-global/the-inspiring-story-of-simon-arias-entrepreneur-philanthropist-44ea1db5bc2e | accessdate =15 June 2018}}</ref> He received a football scholarship to [[Mercyhurst University]] in [[Erie, Pennsylvania]] where he became team captain and graduated from Mercyhurst College with a Bachelor's degree in [[Business Administration]] and [[Management]] (2001 – 2005).<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Remembering Rapoport: Simon Arias | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''dailylockerroom.com''| date =4 May 2017 | url =http://dailylockerroom.com/2012/05/04/remembering-rapoport-simon-arias/ | accessdate =15 June 2018}}</ref>
==Career== After graduating from the university, Arias was hired by the Surace-Smith Agencies of American Income Life in [[Ohio]] and later become a Regional Manager in the company.<ref name="SCAR">{{cite news | last =Kelly | first =Wilson | title =Simon Arias, Arias Agencies And Their Insurance Products | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''scalar.usc.edu''| date =4 May 2017 | url =http://scalar.usc.edu/works/informative-articles/simon-arias-arias-agencies-and-their-insurance-products | accessdate =15 June 2018}}</ref>
Arias is currently the State General Agent for Pennsylvania, West Virginia, Maryland, Tennessee, & Florida.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Life Insurance Agent in Wexford, PA Simon Arias | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''agency.ailife.com''| date =4 May 2017 | url =https://agency.ailife.com/simonarias/ | accessdate =15 June 2018}}</ref> Arias has been a member of AIL’s Executive Council and he is the only SGA in company history to be named'' State General Agent of the Year'' for two consecutive years.<ref name="SCAR"/>
In May 2008, Simon founded Arias Agencies, a representative of American Income Life Insurance Company.<ref>{{cite news | last =Emily | first =Moorhead | title =Ready for a Career Boost? These Mentorship Options Will Fit Your Busy Lifestyle | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''allbusiness.com''| date =4 May 2017 | url =https://www.allbusiness.com/mentorship-options-fit-busy-lifestyle-113848-1.html | accessdate =15 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Arias Agencies Voted #2 Top Workplace In Pittsburgh | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''pittsburgh.cbslocal.com''| date =24 August 2016 | url =http://pittsburgh.cbslocal.com/2016/08/24/arias-agencies-voted-2-top-workplace-in-pittsburgh/ | accessdate =15 June 2018}}</ref>
==Philanthropy== Arias established community programs in his hometown of Youngstown, OH. He helped bring the youth program, ''Inspiring Minds'', to Youngstown, and he has partnered with [[Maurice Clarett]] to open ''The Red Zone'', a company whose mission is to help youth at-risk and their families.<ref>{{cite news | last =Morgan | first =Petronelli| title =The Red Zone Aspires To Change Youngstown Lives | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''thejambar.com''| date =21 August 2017 | url =http://www.thejambar.com/red-zone-aspires-change-youngstown-lives/ | accessdate =15 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="THE">{{cite news | last =Wilson | first =Kelly | title =Simon Arias Entrepreneur — Learning From His Success and Achievements | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''thebaynet.com''| date = | url =http://www.thebaynet.com/community/technology/simon-arias-entrepreneur-learning-from-his-success-and-achievements.html | accessdate =15 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Simon Arias Shares His Stunning Business Hacks to Help Your Brand Thrive | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''homebusinessmag.com''| date =3 April 2018 | url =https://homebusinessmag.com/growing-a-business/how-to-guides-growing-a-business/simon-arias-shares-stunning-business-hacks-help-brand-thrive/ | accessdate =15 June 2018}}</ref>
==Awards and honors== * 2011 and 2012 - State General Agent (SGA) of the year Award (two consecutive years)<ref name="THE"/>
* 2017 - Young Alumnus Award by Mercyhurst University<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Mercyhurst honors Distinguished Alumni | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''mercyhurst.edu''| date =16 June 2017 | url =http://www.mercyhurst.edu/news/mercyhurst-honors-distinguished-alumni-0 | accessdate =15 June 2018}}</ref>
==See also== * [[American Income Life Insurance Company]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.ariasagencies.com/ Arias Agencies Official website]

{{Multiple issues| {{BLP refimprove|date=December 2015}} {{More footnotes|date=December 2015}}}} {{Infobox person | name = Stanko Subotić | image = Stanko Subotic Cane.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1959|09|09}} | birth_place = [[Kalinovac (Ub)|Kalinovac]], [[People's Republic of Serbia|PR Serbia]], [[Federal People's Republic of Yugoslavia|FPR Yugoslavia]] | occupation = Entrepreneur
Owner of [[D Trade]], Futura Plus, Famis LLC | networth = | spouse = Jagoda | children = 1 | residence = [[Geneva, Switzerland]] | website = http://www.stanko-subotic.com | signature = Cane signature.jpg }} '''Stanko "Cane" Subotić''' (born 9 September 1959, [[Kalinovac (Ub)|Kalinovac]], [[People's Republic of Serbia|PR Serbia]], [[Federal People's Republic of Yugoslavia|FPR Yugoslavia]]) is a [[Geneva]]-based Serbian businessman. He was sentenced to six years imprisonment for abuse of office,{{clarify|date=January 2016}} but the case is on appeal. Subotić is the founder and owner of the [[Denmark]]-based company EMI (Emerging Marketing Investment) and [[D Trade]] (based in Belgrade, Serbia), dealing in sales and distribution of wine, paper and real estate. Additionally, he is the co-owner of Serbia-based [[Futura Plus]], a commercial distribution network in Southeastern Europe. In Serbia, his companies employ over 4,000 people.{{citation needed|date=November 2007}} Additionally, Subotić is the co-owner of the meat processing factory Famis LLC (founded in 2002 in Serbia), as well as distribution companies in [[Greece]] and [[Russia]] dealing in non-alcoholic beverages and sporting equipment. Moreover, he bought hundreds of acres of vineyards in [[France]], which he uses for production of the wine Louis Max, which has been served at the [[White House]].[http://www.b92.net/info/emisije/insajder.php?yyyy=2006&mm=05&nav_id=197780] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060522054819/http://www.b92.net/info/emisije/insajder.php?yyyy=2006&mm=05&nav_id=197780 |date=22 May 2006 }} He began investing in this company in 1989, and since January 2007 he is the sole owner of Max Holding. Subotić owns a wine cellar in downtown [[Belgrade]] and the luxury hotel Villa Montenegro on [[Sveti Stefan]] island. In March 2007, this hotel was awarded the "Five Stars Diamond" award for the quality of service by the [[American Academy of Hospitality Sciences]].{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} ==Early life and business career== Subotić came from a working-class family, to which he was born as the sixth and youngest child. During early childhood, he started working in his father's carpentry shop. A Serbian national by birth, since 1999 He completed the streamlined High School of Economics in [[Ub, Serbia|Ub]], where he met his future wife Jagoda. He started earning an independent living in his early twenties when he left for [[France]] and got a job as a tailor. He opened a chain of clothing boutiques, and developed his own wholesale and retail.{{citation needed|date=August 2007}} During mid-1980s he invested into Serbian economy, by supplying civil engineering equipment which he judged to be in short supply. Subotić started his private business career in 1991 following the collapse of communism in [[SFR Yugoslavia]] by founding a company named MIA and opening a sewing shop that cooperated with state owned [[retailer]] [[Robna kuća Beograd|Robne kuće Beograd]]. From that time until the year 1993, his primary business activities were textile production and confection.{{cn|date=December 2015}} By 1995, he entered the cigarette trade in [[Federal Republic of Yugoslavia]], a country under a [[United Nations|UN]] imposed [[trade embargo]]. Subotić owned two duty-free shops at the Đeneral Janković border crossing and in 1996 became exclusive distributor of foreign cigarette producers such as [[Philip Morris International|Philip Morris]] and [[British American Tobacco]]. His cigarette trading business was initially based in Serbia, but, in 1997, after Vlada "Tref" Kovačević and Radovan "Badža" Stojičić were murdered, Subotić relocated his entire business to [[Montenegro]] and moved there, where he established high political and business connections with the republic's Prime Minister [[Milo Đukanović]] and ruling [[Democratic Party of Socialists of Montenegro|DPS]] party president [[Svetozar Marović]].{{cite web|url=http://www.blic.co.rs/temadana.php?id=5486|title=Mira i Marko predvodili jednu od mafijaških grupa|website=Blic.co.rs|date=9 June 2007|accessdate=16 January 2016}} In 2003, Subotić opened a subsidiary in Montenegro, which is in operation to this day. The same year, he acquired the Serbian company [[Duvan]], owner of a large distribution network which included retail booths and kiosks selling printed media and other consumer goods, and founded the company [[Futura plus]]. After acquiring Duvan, in 2004, he began collaborating with the German media holding group [[WAZ-Mediengruppe|WAZ]], which brought him new points of sale as it acquired a majority stake at [[Politika AD|Politika distribution]]. Futura Plus now owns the largest media distribution network in Serbia with a large number of kiosks and newspaper stands, previously owned by Duvan, Politika distribution, [[Borba (newspaper)|Borba distribution]] and [[Duvanpromet]] from [[Kragujevac]]. After Serbian Prosecution raised accusations against Subotic in 2008, WAZ Media Group left Futura plus.{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/biz/vesti/srbija.php?yyyy=2008&mm=05&dd=08&nav_id=297516|title=VAC prodao udeo u "Futuri plus"|website=B92.net|date=8 May 2008|accessdate=16 January 2016}} In Montenegro he founded a company named Montenegro Futura that owns a similar distribution network throughout the country.{{cn|date=December 2015}} In 2005, Subotić moved his business headquarters to [[Cyprus]]. During the Spring 2007, Subotić additionally expanded his activities with two large investments in Montenegro: purchasing a piece of the island of St Nikola near the port of [[Budva]] from a Serbian businessman, Nenad Đorđević, for approximately [[€]]24 million and announcing his plans to build a luxury hotel worth [[€]]20 million on the St. Stefan island.[http://www.mtsmondo.com/news/vesti/story.php?vest=52391] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927010608/http://www.mtsmondo.com/news/vesti/story.php?vest=52391 |date=27 September 2007 }} ==Controversy== Throughout the 2000s and 2010s, Subotić faced numerous allegations and accusations of smuggling, tax evasion, and state budget defrauding stemming from 1990s cigarette trade in the [[Federal Republic of Yugoslavia]] that was under a UN trade embargo at the time.{{cn|date=December 2015}} ===The ''Nacional'' affair=== In May 2001, Croatia's ''[[Nacional (weekly)|Nacional]]'' newsmagazine, owned and edited by [[Ivo Pukanić]], published detailed accounts of Subotić's activities, claiming they involved organized crime figures as well as the highest echelons of the Montenegrin and Serbian political regimes. Largely unknown and unexposed up to that point, the entire ''Nacional'' affair forced Subotić into the public limelight as he began giving occasional interviews in the Serbian media. He responded that the news stories were fabrications paid for and planted by a competing Croatian tobacco producer, [[Tvornica duhana Rovinj]], supposedly threatened by Subotić's plans to jointly build a tobacco factory in Serbia with British American Tobacco in 2001.{{cite web|url=http://arhiva.glas-javnosti.rs/arhiva/2003/01/10/pisma/srpski/pisma.shtml|title=Stanko Subotić Cane: Moj deo istine|website=Arhiva.glas-javnosti.rs|accessdate=16 January 2016}} Over the coming years, Subotić filed a series of lawsuits against ''Nacional'' and its owner/editor-in-chief Pukanić in [[Zagreb]] on the grounds of slander. In Croatia, Subotić was represented by a Croatian lawyer, Slobodan Budak. ''Nacional'' claimed that "Subotić lost each one of the 26 lawsuits he filed against the magazine", while Subotić's lawyer in Serbia, Vlado Pavićević, claimed his client has "at least nine court verdicts in his favour".{{cite web|url=http://www.politika.rs/rubrike/Hronika/t31491.sr.html|title=Политика Online|website=Politika.rs|accessdate=16 January 2016}} ===2006 ''Insajder'' interview=== In mid 2006, Subotić was hit with a new series of accusations when findings of the 2003 Serbian police investigation (soubriquetted "Mreža") were obtained by several media outlets, including [[B92]]. In it, Subotić's involvement in cigarette trade between 1995 and 1999 is characterized as "smuggling without taxation made possible by high ranking members of [[Slobodan Milošević|Milošević]]'s regime". On 15 May 2006, Subotić's taped interview with journalist [[Brankica Stanković]] aired on B92's ''[[Insajder]]'' programme. In it he claimed to have been shown the results of "Mreža" investigation way back in 2003 by then Serbian Interior Minister [[Dušan Mihajlović (politician)|Dušan Mihajlović]]. Subotić added that Mihajlović reassured him on the same occasion that he (Subotić) is not in any way subject of investigation, telling him that "your (Subotić's) business activities during the 1990s were found to be legit".{{cn|date=January 2016}} ===2007 'Mreža' arrests and Interpol arrest warrant=== On 6 June 2007 Serbian police arrested eight individuals, which it believes were part of a 15-person criminal group organized by Subotić. Subotić himself was not placed under arrest that day, because the police could not find him, however, an [[Interpol]] arrest warrant was later issued for him. The arrested individuals were placed in a 48-hour detention, and they include: *Milan Popivoda, former chief of Novi Sad state security branch *Miodrag Zavišić, former chief of Novi Sad police department *Nebojša "Tarzan" Nikolić and Drage Dodeski, former federal customs bureau employees *Milan "Mrgud" Milanović, former employee of different federal bodies and a prominent member of Škorpioni paramilitary unit. Since 2002 co-owner of Famis d.o.o. meat factory with Subotić{{cite web|url=http://www.politika.rs/rubrike/Hronika/t30687.sr.html|title=Политика Online|website=Politika.rs|accessdate=16 January 2016}} *Milan "Pekin" Ranković, an employee in Subotić's MIA company *Ivana Olujić, accused of acting as a proxy in cigarette smuggling *Miroslav "Miki" Pešić, accused of making payments on behalf of Subotić's MIA company. On the same day, the [[Serbian Ministry of the Interior]] (MUP) issued a press release saying: "These arrests occurred following a detailed and thorough investigation taking place over several years in collaboration with special persecutor's office in regard to "Mreža" investigation. Subotić's group is being accused of illegally importing cigarettes and selling them on the [[black market]]. By doing so they defrauded the state budget of [[Deutsche Mark|DM]]80 million in unpaid tax. The money they made in Serbia was transferred to their accounts in [[Cyprus]] via [[Montenegro]] and [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]]".[http://www.mtsmondo.com/news/vesti/text.php?vest=59522] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070608104436/http://www.mtsmondo.com/news/vesti/text.php?vest=59522 |date=8 June 2007 }} In addition to Subotić, six other individuals were sought by police on the same occasion: Ivan Krčmaričić, Đorđe Subotić, Luka Nenadić, Jovica Ranđelović, Stevan Banović, and Nikola Milošević (Subotić's nephew). Subotić eventually responded to the charges through a press release forwarded to Montenegrin state news agency MINA on 26 June 2007. He claimed innocence adding he did business in line with widely used practices at the time, and added, "The goal of this thing that's started by [[Belgrade]] is to smear my reputation in front of my business partners in [[Serbia]] and the rest of [[Europe]], but I'm not the main target. This will turn into one more attack on [[Montenegro]] by those that are pathologically obsessed with its independence, like they were with [[Zoran Đinđić|Đinđić]] all until his death." Subotić accused Montenegrin opposition leader [[Nebojša Medojević]] of insinuations and of "writing newspaper columns that helped create the atmosphere for the murder of Zoran Đinđić". Subotić concluded by saying: "Medojević and [[Vojislav Koštunica]] are working on the satanization of the Montenegrin state by creating an impression of its supposed criminalization".{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/info/vesti/index.php?yyyy=2007&mm=06&dd=26&nav_id=252762|title=Subotić: Nisam švercovao cigarete|website=B92.net|date=26 June 2007|accessdate=16 January 2016}} ===2008 arrest and two-month detention in Moscow=== On 28 April 2008, Subotić was arrested in [[Moscow]] at [[Sheremetyevo International Airport]] based on an [[Interpol]] red notice warrant issued against him by the Serbian police.{{cite web|url=http://www.blic.rs/hronika.php?id=39776|title=Cane uhapšen u Moskvi|website=Blic.rs|date=29 April 2008|accessdate=16 January 2016}} Though initially it looked like he'd be transferred to native [[Serbia]] where he's indicted on smuggling and tax fraud charges, and despite the fact that Serbian authorities sent an official extradition request for him to Russia, the Russian authorities let him go free on 27 June 2008.[http://www.mtsmondo.com/news/world/text.php?vest=101454] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080709015514/http://www.mtsmondo.com/news/world/text.php?vest=101454 |date=9 July 2008 }} ===B92 Interview, 16 March 2010=== Subotić accused [[Nebojša Medojević]], the [[Montenegro|Montenegrin]] party leader of [[Movement for Change]] of having organized a manhunt on him on the orders of [[Serbia]]n businessman [[Milan Beko]] and Delta Holding owner Miroslav Mišković after they stole 50 million from Subotić to buy [[Port of Belgrade]] and daily newspaper [[Večernje Novosti]]. Medojević had claimed that Subotić and Darko Šarić had been hiding in a Montenegrin police villa in [[Žabljak]], while Subotić claimed in an interview that he was in [[Geneva, Switzerland]].[http://www.b92.net/eng/news/politics-article.php?yyyy=2010&mm=03&dd=16&nav_id=65829] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131221052039/http://www.b92.net/eng/news/politics-article.php?yyyy=2010&mm=03&dd=16&nav_id=65829 |date=21 December 2013 }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.futuraplus.rs/ Futura Plus] *[http://www.louismax.com/ Louis Max] *[http://www.b92.net/biz/vesti/region.php?yyyy=2007&mm=03&dd=28&nav_id=238783 Cane Subotić gradi hotel u C. Gori], B92.net, 28 March 2007 *[http://www.b92.net/info/vesti/index.php?yyyy=2007&mm=06&dd=06&nav_category=120&nav_id=250127 Prva hapšenja u aferi "Mreža"], B92.net, 6 June 2007 *[https://archive.is/20140519191724/http://www.politika.rs/detaljno.php?nid=31495&lang=2 Raspisana poternica za Subotićem], Politika.rs, 15 June 2007 {{DEFAULTSORT:Subotic, Stanko}} [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Ub, Serbia]] [[Category:Serbian businesspeople]]

{{for|the cable and satellite channel that launched in 2009|MLB Network}} {{redirect|Baseball Night in America|telecasts with that branding beginning in 2012|Fox Major League Baseball}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox television | show_name = The Baseball Network | image = The Baseball Network logo.png | caption = The Baseball Network title card | show_name_2 = '''Baseball Night in America''' | genre = [[Baseball]] [[Sports broadcasting|telecasts]] | creator = | director = | presenter = [[The Baseball Network announcers|Various]] | theme_music_composer = [[Scott Schreer]]{{YouTube|title=Baseball Network Theme 1994 1995 (Various Cuts)|id=XNwe5F-zsnY}}{{YouTube|title=1994 MLB All Star Game Three Rivers, PA|id=WABo44AEns8}} | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = | country = United States | language = English | num_seasons = 2 | num_episodes = | list_episodes = | executive_producer = | producer = | editor = | location = | camera = [[Multi-camera setup|Multi-camera]] | runtime = 210 minutes or until end of game | company = [[Major League Baseball]]
[[ESPN on ABC|ABC Sports]]
[[NBC Sports]] | distributor = | network = [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]
[[NBC]] | picture_format = [[480i]] ([[Standard-definition television|SDTV]]) | first_aired = {{Start date|1994|07|12}} | last_aired = {{End date|1995|10|28}} | preceded_by = ''[[Major League Baseball on CBS]]'' ([[1990 Major League Baseball season|1990]]–[[1993 Major League Baseball season|1993]]) | followed_by = ''[[Fox Major League Baseball]]'' ([[1996 Major League Baseball season|1996]]-present) | related = ''[[Major League Baseball on ABC]]''
''[[Major League Baseball on NBC]]'' | website = | production_website = }} '''The Baseball Network''' was a short-lived [[broadcasting|television broadcasting]] [[joint venture]] between [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]], [[NBC]] and [[Major League Baseball]].{{cite news|title=Major League Baseball Strikes Unique Deal with NBC, ABC|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/289457/MAJOR-LEAGUE-BASEBALL-STRIKES-UNIQUE-DEAL-WITH-NBC-ABC.html?pg=all|author=John Nelson|newspaper=[[Deseret News]]|date=May 9, 1993}} Under the arrangement, beginning in the [[1994 Major League Baseball season|1994 season]], the league produced its own in-house{{cite book |last=Shea|first=Stuart|date= |title=Calling the Game: Baseball Broadcasting from 1920 to the Present|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p5QcCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA47&dq=Calling+the+Game:+Baseball+Broadcasting+from+1920+to+the+Present&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjv5urTwYPWAhXhjFQKHUvRBWEQ6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=ABC&f=false|location= |publisher=SABR, Inc.|page=360|isbn= |author-link= }} telecasts of games,{{cite web|title=Sports Graphics Packages, Historically: MLB on ABC, 1994-1995|url=http://boards.sportslogos.net/topic/93118-sports-graphics-packages-historically/page-4#entry2117800|website=SportsLogos.net|date=November 10, 2013}} which were then [[Brokered programming|brokered]] to air on ABC and NBC. This was perhaps most evident by the copyright beds shown at the end of the telecasts, which stated "The proceeding program has been paid for by the office of [[Commissioner of Baseball|The Commissioner of Baseball]]".{{YouTube|title=MLB World Series 28.10.1995 Cleveland Indians VS Atlanta Braves (Game 5)|id=rVlMs-xgItY}} The Baseball Network was the first television network in the United States to be owned by a professional sports league.{{cite book|title=Total Sportscasting: Performance, Production, and Career Development|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3qTcAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT54&dq=Major+League+Baseball+on+CBS&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEcQ6AEwBjhGahUKEwiY4detpoDJAhWWNIgKHQkhDXY#v=onepage&q=The%20Baseball%20Network&f=false|author=Marc Zumoff|author2=Max Negin|publisher= |year= |isbn= |page=}} In essence, The Baseball Network could be seen as a forerunner to the [[MLB Network]]{{cite web |url=http://www.afootinthebox.com/peter/the-baseball-network-1994-1995|title=The Baseball Network (1994-1995) — A Foot In The Box|last=Elliott|first=Peter|date=September 24, 2017|website=A Foot In The Box|publisher= |access-date= |quote=}}, which would debut about 15 years later. The package{{cite book|title=Center Field Shot: A History of Baseball on Television|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6kPQhpS-X8YC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Center+Field+Shot:+A+History+of+Baseball+on+Television&hl=en&sa=X&ei=GyN-UdfsNan3igL5yoBQ&ved=0CD4Q6AEwAA#v=snippet&q=The%20Baseball%20Network&f=false|author=James Robert Walker|author2=Robert Bellamy, Jr.|publisher= |year= |isbn= |page=155}} included coverage of games in [[Prime time|primetime]]{{cite news |last=Silverman|first=Robert|date=February 15, 1994|title=Primetime baseball hits NBC, ABC weak nights|url=https://variety.com/1994/tv/news/primetime-baseball-hits-nbc-abc-weak-nights-118371/|work=Variety|location= |access-date= }} on selected nights throughout the regular season (under the branding '''''Baseball Night in America'''''{{cite news |last=Martzke|first=Rudy|date=17 July 1995|title=THE GOOD AND BAD OF BASEBALL NIGHT IN AMERICA|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Daily/Issues/1995/07/17/Sports-Media/THE-GOOD-AND-BAD-OF-BASEBALL-NIGHT-IN-AMERICA.aspx?hl=ABC&sc=0|newspaper=Sports Business Daily|location= |access-date= }}), along with coverage of the [[Major League Baseball postseason|postseason]] and the [[World Series]].{{cite news|title=Primetime baseball hits NBC, ABC weak nights|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR118371?categoryid=1011&cs=1|author=Robert Silverman|newspaper=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=February 15, 1994|accessdate=July 2, 2012}} Unlike previous broadcasting arrangements with the league, there was no national "[[Major League Baseball Game of the Week|game of the week]]"{{cite news |last=Kent|first=Milton|date=17 July 1995|title=Void grows on Saturday afternoon|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1995-07-17/sports/1995198007_1_baseball-network-afternoon-baseball-grand-old-game|newspaper=The Baltimore Sun|location= |access-date= }} during the regular season;{{cite news|title=No More Baseball On Afternoon TV -- `Baseball Night' Will Start In July|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19940403&slug=1903562|author=Michael Martinez|newspaper=[[The Seattle Times]]|date=April 3, 1994}} these would be replaced by multiple weekly regional{{cite news|title='Baseball Night in America' will focus on regionalized fan appeal |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2209&dat=19940717&id=coJKAAAAIBAJ&sjid=zpMMAAAAIBAJ&pg=1345,3484132|author=John Nelson|newspaper=[[The Telegraph (Nashua)|The Telegraph]]|date=July 17, 1994}} telecasts on certain nights of the week. Additionally, The Baseball Network had exclusive coverage windows; no other broadcaster could televise MLB games during the same night that The Baseball Network was televising games. The arrangement did not last long; due to the effects of a [[1994–95 Major League Baseball strike|players' strike]] on the remainder of the 1994 season,{{cite news|title=TV SPORTS; Account Running Dry For Baseball Network|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/02/sports/tv-sports-account-running-dry-for-baseball-network.html|author=[[Richard Sandomir]]|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=September 2, 1994}} and poor reception from fans and critics over how the coverage{{cite news|title=The Baseball Network Adds Up To Bad Reception|url=http://articles.courant.com/1995-10-26/sports/9510260433_1_baseball-network-bob-costas-coverage|author=Jerry Trecker|newspaper=Hartford Courant|date=October 26, 1995|accessdate=July 2, 2012}}{{cite news|title=Nitwits Running Baseball Network|url=http://www.sfgate.com/sports/article/Nitwits-Running-Baseball-Network-3022121.php|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|date=October 7, 1995|accessdate=July 2, 2012}}{{cite news|title=Baseball Network ruining hardball's comeback|url=http://www.collegian.psu.edu:8080/archive/1995/10/10-05-95tdc/10-05-95dsports-column.asp|author=Kevin Gorman|newspaper=[[The Daily Collegian]]|date=October 5, 1995|accessdate=August 21, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130620071949/http://www.collegian.psu.edu:8080/archive/1995/10/10-05-95tdc/10-05-95dsports-column.asp|archive-date=20 June 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|title=The Baseball Network: R.I.P. (And Don't Come Back!)|url=http://roadsidephotos.sabr.org/baseball/95-3TV.htm|author=Doug Pappas|website=roadsidephotos.sabr.org|date=}}{{cite web|title=Baseball Night In America: The Worst Idea Ever|url=http://stholeary.blogspot.com/2011/07/baseball-night-in-america-worst-idea.html|author=Sean O'Leary|website=Scribblings|date=July 12, 2011}}{{cite news |last=Nelson|first=John|date=October 10, 1995|title=Baseball, networks should be ashamed|url=http://journaltimes.com/news/national/baseball-networks-should-be-ashamed/article_4858ba87-37fb-5938-8af1-b945a1da3220.html|newspaper=The Journal Times|location= |access-date= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.thisgreatgame.com/baseball-lists-ten-worst-promotions.html|title=The 10 Worst Promotional Ideas in Baseball History|last= |first= |date= |website=This Great Game|publisher= |access-date= |quote=}} was implemented, The Baseball Network would be disbanded after the 1995 season{{cite web |url=http://www.thisgreatgame.com/1995-baseball-history.html|title=1995 Thanks to Cal, Hideo—& Sonia, Too|last= |first= |date= |website=This Great Game|publisher= |access-date= |quote=}}. While NBC would maintain rights to certain games, the growing [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] network (having established its own sports division two years earlier in 1994) became the league's [[Major League Baseball on Fox|new national broadcast partner]]{{cite news|title=Baseball On TV -- FOX Bid Helps Put Baseball Back On Track |url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19960327&slug=2321309|author=Bob Sherwin|newspaper=The Seattle Times|date=March 27, 1996}} beginning in 1996, with its then-parent company [[News Corporation]] eventually purchasing the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] in 1998 (although the company has since sold the team). ==Background== After the fall-out from [[Major League Baseball on CBS|CBS]]'s financial problems{{cite news|title=TV SPORTS; The Baseball Network Says the Players' Analyst Struck Out |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/08/26/sports/tv-sports-the-baseball-network-says-the-players-analyst-struck-out.html|author=Richard Sandomir|newspaper=The New York Times|date=August 26, 1994|accessdate=July 2, 2012}} from their exclusive, four-year-long, US$1.8 billion television contract with Major League Baseball (a contract that ultimately cost the network approximately $500 million{{cite news|title=Baseball Network Plans to Bring on the Night New TV Deal Makes Saturday Afternoon Games a Thing of the Past|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SJ&s_site=mercurynews&p_multi=SJ&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB71CC84CEA49AA&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=April 3, 1994|accessdate=May 31, 2011}}), Major League Baseball decided to go into the business of producing the telecasts themselves{{cite book |last= Walker, Bellamy|first=James R., Robert V.|date= |title=Center Field Shot: A History of Baseball on Television|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6kPQhpS-X8YC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Center+Field+Shot:+A+History+of+Baseball+on+Television&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiB-fHOvLPXAhWJ7CYKHbXpAK4Q6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=The%20Baseball%20Network&f=false|location= |publisher= U of Nebraska Press|page=156|isbn= |author-link= }} and market these to advertisers on its own. In reaction to the failed trial with CBS{{cite news |last=Shea|first=Jim|date=October 6, 1995|title=Baseball Network A Turnoff, But Ch. 30 Did A Good Job|url=http://articles.courant.com/1995-10-06/sports/9510060419_1_baseball-network-abc-and-nbc-cable-or-network-television|work=Hartford Courant|location= |access-date= }}, Major League Baseball was desperately grasping for every available dollar. To put things into proper perspective, in [[1991 Major League Baseball season|1991]], the second year of the league's contract with the network, CBS reported a loss of around $169 million in the third quarter of the year. A decline in advertiser interest caused revenue from the sale of commercials during CBS's baseball telecasts to plummet. All the while, CBS was still contractually obligated to pay Major League Baseball around $260 million a year through [[1993 Major League Baseball season|1993]].{{cite book|title=Stee-Rike Four!: What's Wrong With the Business of Baseball?|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R4fBTgkTMKYC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=The%20Baseball%20Network&f=false|page=57|publisher= |isbn=|year= }} Before Major League Baseball decided to seek the services of other networks, CBS offered US$120 million in annual rights fees over a two-year period,{{cite news|title=McCarver prefers all 4 games|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/USAToday/access/72750573.html?dids=72750573:72750573&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Oct+06%2C+1995&author=Rudy+Martzke&pub=USA+TODAY+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=McCarver+prefers+all+4+games&pqatl=google|author=Rudy Martzke|newspaper=USA Today|date=October 6, 1995}}{{cite news |last=Stewart|first=Larry|date=14 May 1993|title=CBS Makes a Late Pitch to Keep Baseball in Its Picture|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1993-05-14/sports/sp-35233_1_abc-and-nbc|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times|location= |access-date= }}{{cite news |last=McClellan|first=Steve|date=17 May 1993|title=Two ways to go on baseball – CBS vs. ABC-NBC. (Major League Baseball joint venture preempted by CBS revenue-sharing deal)|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-13768400.html|newspaper=Broadcasting & Cable|location= |access-date= }} as well as advertising revenues in excess of $150 million a season. As part of MLB's attempt to produce and market the games in-house, it hoped to provide games of regional interests to appropriate markets. Major League Baseball in the process, hoped to offer important games for divisional races to the overall market. Owners also hoped that this particular technique, combined with the additional division races created through league expansion (the [[Colorado Rockies]] and [[Florida Marlins]] had begun play the year prior) and the quest for wild card spots for the playoffs ([[1994 Major League Baseball season|1994]] was the first year of three divisions for each league) would increase{{cite book |last=Wise and Meyer|first=Aaron N. and Bruce S.|date= |title=International Sports Law and Business, Volume 3|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oSix-O4CmvMC&pg=PA1701&lpg=PA1701&dq=the+baseball+network+cbs+major+league+baseball+1994&source=bl&ots=4LPhUOnH9I&sig=EWr4SKGx7BQkCIpPJ92mgaxmRv8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=DNHqVK2KB8bloASDhYHoDg&ved=0CCUQ6AEwATgK#v=onepage&q=the%20baseball%20network%20cbs%20major%20league%20baseball%201994&f=false|location= |publisher= |page=1701|isbn= |access-date= }} the national broadcast revenue for Major League Baseball in the foreseeable future. After a four-year hiatus, [[Major League Baseball on ABC|ABC]] and [[Major League Baseball on NBC|NBC]]{{cite news|title=With Baseball Back, Nbc Pulls Out Its Own All-star Lineup|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1994-07-11/sports/9407110170_1_bob-costas-andy-rosenberg-all-star-lineup|author=Steve Nidetz|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=July 11, 1994|accessdate=February 10, 2015}} (who [[1989 Major League Baseball season|last]] aired ''[[Thursday Night Baseball]]'' games and the Saturday afternoon ''[[Major League Baseball Game of the Week|Game of the Week]]''{{cite news|title=Mulholland Ought to Grow Up, Graf Pay Up|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SA&p_theme=sa&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAFECD95B5E280D&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|author=Rick Rupprecht|newspaper=[[Press Democrat]]|date=August 5, 1995|accessdate=May 31, 2011}} respectively) returned to Major League Baseball under the umbrella of a [[revenue]] sharing venture called '''The Baseball Network'''.{{cite web |url=http://www.nbcsports.com/our-history#decade_7|title=NBC enters joint venture with ABC and MLB to form The Baseball Network|last= |first= |date= |website=NBC Sports History Page|publisher= |access-date= |quote=}}{{cite news|title=Name chosen for baseball's joint TV venture|url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl/1993_1149392/name-chosen-for-baseball-s-joint-tv-venture.html|newspaper=[[Houston Chronicle]]|date=August 25, 1993|accessdate=July 2, 2012}}{{cite journal|title=For Sale: The National Pastime|url=http://cnnsi.printthis.clickability.com/pt/cpt?action=cpt&title=Baseball+worked+out+a+risky+new+TV+deal+with+ABC+and+NBC+-+05.17.93+-+SI+Vault&expire=&urlID=432445957&fb=Y&url=http%3A%2F%2Fsportsillustrated.cnn.com%2Fvault%2Farticle%2Fmagazine%2FMAG1138205%2Findex.htm&partnerID=289881|author=William Oscar Johnson|journal=[[Sports Illustrated]]|date=May 17, 1993}} Under a six-year plan (with an option for two additional years{{cite book |last=Wise, Meyer|first=Aaron N., Bruce S.|date= |title=International Sports Law and Business, Volume 3|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oSix-O4CmvMC&pg=PA1702&lpg=PA1702&dq=the+baseball+network+1994+nbc&source=bl&ots=4MPjQOrO8M&sig=uQN405cS0CBHz_Fd8QGiTiuK6mM&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi_rvmfy4TbAhUCoYMKHSP9Dyk4HhDoAQhlMA4#v=onepage&q=the%20baseball%20network%201994%20nbc&f=false|location= |publisher= Kluwer Law International|page=1701|isbn= |author-link= }}), Major League Baseball was intended to receive 85[[Percentage|%]] of the first US$140 million in advertising{{cite news|title=MEDIA NHL Steals The Show And Ratings|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/newsday/access/101864421.html?dids=101864421:101864421&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jun+17%2C+1994&author=Steve+Zipay&pub=Newsday+(Combined+editions)&desc=MEDIA+NHL+Steals+The+Show+And+Ratings&pqatl=google|author=Steve Zipay|newspaper=[[Newsday]]|date=June 17, 1994|accessdate=May 31, 2011}} revenue (or 87.5%{{cite book |last=Bartkowiak, Kiuchi|first=Mathew J., Yuya|date= |title=Packaging Baseball: How Marketing Embellishes the Cultural Experience|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IwbFSRZVMf4C&pg=PA82&dq=The+Baseball+Network+1994&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEQQ6AEwBjgUahUKEwjeq8vxqYDJAhVV4WMKHTXCAu8#v=onepage&q=The%20Baseball%20Network%201994&f=false|location= |publisher= |page=82|isbn=}} of advertising revenues{{cite news|title=Baseball tries for comeback, but it swings and misses.|url=http://business.highbeam.com/137540/article-1G1-17493415/baseball-tries-comeback-but-swings-and-misses|author=Chad Rubel|newspaper=Marketing News|date=September 11, 1995|accessdate=July 2, 2012}} and corporate sponsorship{{cite news|title=Firms May Take a Walk On Baseball Promotions|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/1995/0307/07082.html|author=Shelley Donald Coolidge|newspaper=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|date=March 7, 1995}} from the games until sales topped a specified level), 50% of the next $30 million, and 80% of any additional money. Prior to this, Major League Baseball was projected to take a projected 55% cut in rights fees and receive a typical rights fee from the networks. When compared to the previous TV deal with CBS, The Baseball Network was supposed to bring in 50% less of the broadcasting revenue. The advertisers{{cite news|title=Baseball Network Fails to Wow Advertisers|url=http://adage.com/article/news/baseball-network-fails-wow-advertisers/88293/|author=Joe Mandese|newspaper=[[Advertising Age]]|date=February 28, 1994|accessdate=July 2, 2012}} were reportedly excited about the arrangement with The Baseball Network because the new package included several changes intended to boost [[Nielsen ratings|ratings]], especially among younger viewers. Arranging broadcasts through The Baseball Network seemed, on the surface, to benefit NBC and ABC (who each contributed $10 million in start-up funds{{cite news |last=Shaprio|first=Leonard|date=September 18, 1993|title=Untangling Baseball Network's Intricacies|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1755&dat=19930918&id=lgocAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YXsEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6968,2958950&hl=en|newspaper=Sarasota Herald-Tribune|location= |access-date= }}) since it gave them a [[monopoly]] on broadcasting Major League Baseball games. The deal was similar to a [[Brokered programming|time-buy]], instead of a traditional rights fee{{cite news|title=Baseball on Disney? It's fantasy land|author=Jack Craig|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/21306329.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Aug+06%2C+1995&author=Jack+Craig%2C+Globe+Staff&pub=Boston+Globe+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=Baseball+on+Disney%3F+It's+fantasy+land&pqatl=google|newspaper=[[Boston Globe]]|date=August 5, 1995|accessdate=May 31, 2011}} situation. It also stood to benefit the networks because they reduced the risk associated with purchasing the broadcast rights outright (in stark contrast to CBS's disastrous contract with Major League Baseball from the 1990–1993 seasons). NBC and ABC were to create a loss-free environment for each other and keep an emerging [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]], which had recently made an aggressive and ultimately successful $1.58 billion bid for the [[NFL on television|television rights]] for [[National Football Conference]] games (thus, becoming a major player in the sports broadcasting game in the process), at bay. As a result of Fox's NFL gain, CBS was weakened further by [[1994 United States broadcast TV realignment|affiliate changes]], as a number of stations jumped to Fox from CBS (for example, in [[Detroit]], [[WWJ-TV]] replaced [[WJBK]]). Key figures involved in the creation and production for The Baseball Network: * David Alworth{{cite news|title=The Baseball Network's firing of executive adds to confusion|url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl/1995_1284608/the-baseball-network-s-firing-of-executive-adds-to.html|newspaper=Houston Chronicle|date=July 7, 2012|accessdate=July 2, 2012}} (vice president of broadcasting and production management) * Bill Canter (production manager) * Ed Delaney (vice-president of operations for The Baseball Network) * Carlos DeMolina (production
